content.description: Crimp up the steep arete 15' left of Battle of the Bulge, then climb over the long overhang above near its left end.
content.protection: Unknown - FA on toprope.  Gear-only anchor.
content.location: Steep arete 15' left of Battle of the Bulge.  Easy walk-off.

content.description:
There has been only one reported ascent of this route - Russ Clune climbed it over ten years ago, placing three pairs of two pitons (six pitons total) to protect the roof moves.  It's unknown if he placed the pitons on lead or not.  Regardless, the route is impressive. 

  If you look carefully, you can still see the remains of the rusty pitons under the roof.  It's unlikely that this route will see a second ascent.
content.protection: On the first ascent (either on lead or on rappel), Russ Clune placed six pitons total to protect the roof moves; they are likely no longer viable, as the area seeps quite a bit.  Do NOT TR this route; the pendulum is severe, and the awaiting trees are always hungry.
content.location: Start at little arete in center of wall under roof, follow holds up tier to small dihedral and out left to tier in roof.  Climb seam in roof out left and over.

content.description:
Start at the bottom of the far right corner of the large roof system. Climb straight up to the corner, traverse left under the roof and out.

 Fairly easy climbing up the corner (after a somewhat interesting mantle at the very beginning). The middle of three sections of roof is very challenging, followed by an easier finish.

 This is classically graded 5.10a but feels extremely stiff for that grade, even by Gunks standards.
content.protection: Trad gear to 3". Can be top-roped only with a lot of care and two ropes. Due to massive swings this requires one top rope at the finish of the climb and one set up near the East LA anchor (or near the corner of the roof) to deaden the huge pendulum swing.
content.location: Far right of the large roof system. The higher roof next to the (much harder) LA Roof.

content.description: The route follows a vertical crack. You can avoid the first move by walking out onto the large boulder. When the crack ends, move maybe 6 feet left until you can mantle up onto the ledge (that is maybe 10' below the top). A step or two back to the right and you can top out. This short route might just possibly pack in more pumpy climbing than any other 5.8 at PK. TR VARIATION - Start 10 ft to the left and climb the arete to the end of the leftwards traverse. Terrific (5.10). OTHER VARIATION - Climb the first 15 ft as usual, then move right a few feet and climb the crack and right-facing flake, passing a laurel bush. Finish in a small notch-recess (5.7ish).
content.protection: Adequate gear if leading's your thing. Normal stuff up to #3 Camalot. But it can be rather "fiddly" to place.
content.location:
Behind the dead hemlock tree that's just right of the huge "LA Roof" roof. 

  2016 update - the hemlock has been cut down.  Look for the stump (and the cut tree lying on the ground).

content.description:
From Phredward: Cross over the jumbled blocks on the ground. Stand up tall to grab good holds on the first crack. Struggle, grunt, and battle your way up the bulge, which is the crux. Continue to easier ground, and pull the roof. 

  For a top rope anchor, there's two big blocks you can sling.
content.location: This route is next to another blazed tree about forty feet right of Acute Corner, and is four feet to the right of a right-facing corner.

content.description: Start on the face a few feet left of Acute Corner. Finish just left of the rounded nose.
content.protection: Looks like PG pro with plenty of horizontal cracks.

content.description: Good route, but the anchor can be very, very tricky - Either bring a LOT of static line and go way back to some acceptable trees, or sling a closer tree, put yourself on rappel, and downclimb/lower to a ledge with more gear options.
content.protection: Pro seems to be on the PG side, and small.  Gear only anchor.
content.location: The route starts in front of a large tree with the blue/yellow blaze.  Start at obvious right-curving seam at bottom, go up and left to edge of small roof (crux), pull through and follow discontinuous seam to top.  Easy walkoff.

content.description: Huge roof, with climbs therein and thereabout.
